full_entry_text: D 1 karı:la:- Hap. leg.; Den. V. fr. 1 karı:. Xak. xı ol erig karı:la:dı: 'he reckoned that the man was advanced in years' (kabīr) 'and attributed an advanced age' (kibar) 'to him' Kaş. III 324 (karı:la:r, karı:la:ma:k); a.o. 329, 29.
D 2 karı:la Hap. leg.; Den. V. fr. 2 karı:. Xak. xı ol yé:rig karı:la:dı: ḍara'a'l-arḍ 'he measured the ground (etc.) in cubits' Kaş. III 324 (followed by 1 karı:la:-); a.o. 329, 15.

?E 3 karı:la:- Hap. leg.; follows the second half of the entry of kara:la:-; prob. an error for karla:- inserted here by a later scribe. Xak. xı tüpi: ka:rığ karı:la:dı: al-rīḥ nafaḥati'l-ṯalc bi-dawī wa ḥafīf 'the wind blew the snow with a confused rustling noise' Kaş. III 324 (karı:la:r, karı:la:ma:k).

D karım N.S.A. fr. 2 ka:r- 'a moat, town ditch', and the like; lit. (a moat filled by) 'a single overflow of water'. Survives with this meaning in NE Tel. R II 183. Uyğ. Bud. (all kinds of poisonous dragons and snakes lie) ol balık (erasure leaving -e at the end; tegre would suit the sense) yeme yét! kat karam (Uyğ.-A form) içinte 'round(?) that town and in the seven-fold moat' PP 39, 4-5: Xak. xı KB (if in a dream you drink half a goblet of water, half your life has finished as a debt; if you drink the whole of it) tükedi tiriglik kazıldı karım 'your life is finished and a grave (lit. ditch) been dug' 6063 (Arat reads kırım, but the word, which is unvocalized, rhymes with yarım and bérim): xııı(?) Tef. bir uluğ karı:m (unvocalized) kazdurdı 'he had a great ditch dug' (and a great fire lit in it) 209 (mistranscribed kırım).

meaning: a single act of placing people according to their rank
full_entry_text: D kura:m Hap. leg.; N.S.A. fr. *kura:-, Den. V. fr. 2 kur; lit. 'a single act of placing people according to their rank'. Xak. xı kura:m kişi:le:r al-nāsu'l-culūs 'alā'l-marātib 'people sitting according to (i.e. in the order of) their ranks' as they sit at the king's gate (bāb); hence one says kişi:le:r kura:m olturdı:la:r 'the people sat according to their ranks' Kaş. I 413.

meaning: a massive rock, or pile of rocks
full_entry_text: korum 'a massive rock, or pile of rocks'; survives in NE Alt., Leb., Şor, Tel. korum R II 561; Khak. xorım Tuv. xorum; SE Turki koram/koyam/kura:m Jarring 252; the second element in the well-known name of the town Karakorum, originally an Uyğ. capital, but mentioned in Mong. as early as xııı (Haenisch 176). Xak. xı korum al-şaxr 'a massive rock'; and 'abundant wealth' (al-mālu'l-camm) is called korum; one says ol korum buldı: wacada māl camm 'he has made a pile' Kaş. I 398; o.o. III 61, 20; 105 (yuvluş-): KB (whatever country my laws reach) ol él barça étlür taş erse korum 'that country is completely organized, even if it is (only) stone and rock' 830: xııı(?) Tef. korum taş 'a rock' 215.

?D karma: 'pillaging; theft'; etymologically connected with 2 karak; not connected with SW Osm. karma in the phr. karma karışık 'muddled, confused' which is a Dev. N./A. fr. 1 kar-; n.o.a.b. Xak. xı karma: al-nahb 'pillaging, theft'; hence one says
    ne:ŋ karma:la:dı: 'he stole (nahaba) the thing' Kaş. I 433; ka:ğu:n karma: bolsa: 'if a melon has been stolen' (nuhiba) I 410, 11.

D kırma: Pass. Dev. N./A. fr. kır-; lit. 'scraped' i.e. to a particular shape. In Ar. xaraṭa means 'to turn (on a lathe)' and maxrūṭ normally 'conical', but with 'ball' it must mean 'spherical'. Survives in SW Az. ğırma 'pellet, shot'; Osm. kırma 'pleat, fold, crease; broken'. Xak. xı kırma: al-maxrūṭ 'turned on a lathe' of anything; hence one says kırma: tobık kura maxrūṭa 'a spherical ball' Kaş. I 433.

F kurma:n 'bow-case'; there is an apparent etymological connection with kuruğluk, same meaning, but the word itself, which is only noted here(?), seems to be a corruption of Pe. qurbān, and that word, though not so far traced in Ar. with this meaning, seems to be derived fr. qaraba, which inter alia means 'to put (something) in a sheath or case'. The word seems therefore to be by origin Ar., or at any rate Pe.-Ar., and one of a number of such words in Oğuz (see 2 turma:), and the connection with kuruğluk illusory. The long note on the word in P. Pelliot, Notes sur l'histoire de la Horde d'Or, Paris, 1950, p. 42, must be corrected accordingly. See also the discussion of Pe. qurbān in Doerfer III 1451. N.o.a.b. Oğuz/Kıp. xı kurma:n al-miqwas, 'bow case'; one says ké:ş kurma:n 'quiver and bow case'; its origin is fr. ku:rma:n (sic, error for ku:rma:k) şuddu'l-minṭaqa fi'l-wasaṭ 'to fasten a belt round the waist' Kaş. I 444; a.o. III 16 (yasık): (Xwar. xıv kurban 'bow-case' Qutb 141): Kıp. xv tirkāş (Pe. l.-w.) 'quiver' (sic) kurman Tuh. 8b. 11.
S karma:- See karva:-.

meaning: he competed with me in pillaging
full_entry_text: S(D) karmaş- as such Hap. leg.; at a later period a Sec. f. of karvaş-; Kaş.'s etymology is, in doubt, correct. Xak. xı ol meniŋ birle: tava:r karmaşdı: 'he competed with me in pillaging (fī nahb) property'; also used for helping (karmaşu:r, karmaşma:k); originally karma:laşdı: (karma:laşu:r, karma:laşma:k) Kaş. II 221.

D kırmaçı: Hap. leg.; N.Ag. fr. kırma:; presumably 'turner', or perhaps more generally 'carpenter'. Xak. xı KB 4458 (in a list of craftsmen; blacksmiths, bootmakers, and) kırmaçı (painters, decorators, arrowmakers, bowmakers).

D kara:muk Den. N. fr. kara:; originally 'tares, corn-cockle', and the like. S.i.m.m.l.g. Xak. xı kara:muk ziwānu'l-ṭa'ām 'tares among the wheat' Kaş. I 487: Çağ. xv ff. karamuk (1) 'a red-coloured fruit like a sour cherry' (ālū bālū), in Ar. za'rūr ('wild plum'); (2) 'black seeds which appear in wheat', in Pe. şaylam ('tares, darnel') or ziwān, beneficial when mixed with sulphur as an ointment for leprosy; (3) metaph., 'a dangerous black pimple which appears on children' (?smallpox) San. 271 v. 12; o.o. 209 v. 17 (syn. w. Rūmī çevrünti 'tares'); 224v. 19 (syn. w. Rūmī delüce ditto): Osm. xvı ff. karamuk (1) 'tares'; (2) 'wild plum'; (3) (once, xvı) 'pimple, rash'; in several texts TTS I 417; II 585; III 409; IV 470.

meaning: a mountain covered with loose rocks
full_entry_text: D korumluğ Hap. leg.; P.N./A. fr. korum. Xak. xı korumluğ ta:ğ cabal ḍū canādil 'a mountain covered with loose rocks' Kaş. I 498.

Kırım karmala- 'to grope about' R II 218 are ultimately der. fr. karva:-, although their morphology is obscure. Xak. xı ol karma:la:dı: ne:ŋni: 'he pillaged (or stole, nahaba) the thing' Kaş. III 354 (karma:la:r, karma:la:ma:k); a.o. I 433 (karma:): (Kom. xıv 'to hurry' (sic?) karmala- CCG; Gr.: Kıp. xıv karmala- massa 'to touch' İd. 69: xv cassa 'to feel, grope' (yoka-, karma-, and) karmala- Tuh. 12a. 13).

D karmalaş- Co-op. f. of karma:la:-; n.o.a.b. Uyğ. vııı ff. Bud. (Sanskrit missing) élig uluşuğ kırmalaş [gap; sic] TT VIII E.17 may belong here, since 'pillaging the realm and country' seems a likely meaning, and a connection with kırma: is improbable: Xak. xı Kaş. II 221 (karmaş-).

meaning: pretended to choke over the water
full_entry_text: D karımsın- Hap. leg.; Refl. Simulative Den. V. fr. *karım, N.S.A. fr. 2 ka:r-; quoted only as an illustration of this form of V. Xak. xı er suvka: karımsındı: 'the man pretended to choke over the water' (an yaşraq bi'l-mā') Kaş. II 260, 24; n.m.e.

karın 'belly, abdomen'; a general term for the lower part of the body and its contents, less specific than kuruğsa:k 'stomach' and bağır- suk 'entrails'. S.i.a.m.l.g., often more specifically for 'womb'. Türkü vııı ff. aḍığıŋ karnı: yarılmiş 'the bear's belly was slit open' IrkB 6: Uyğ. vııı ff. Bud. Sanskrit garbhe 'in the womb' ka:rında: TT VIII D.35; köŋullerin karınların irintürdüm . . . erser 'if I have distressed their minds and feelings' Suv. 136, 10-11; o.o. U II 44, 28-9 (1 ö:g); U III 43, 24 (kéber-): Civ. karın is common in H I for 'stomach', e.g. aç karınka 'on an empty stomach' 19, 64, 170; and 'womb', e.g. (if a foetus dies) kişiniŋ karında 'in a woman's womb' 61; (in an unfavourable omen) kar içinde ig kirdi; ?read karın, 'if an illness has entered the belly' TT I 18; o.o. TT VII 22, 16 (1 öt-); 27, 15 (arkuru:): Xak. xı karın al-baṭn 'the belly'; karın atmak a beast is slaughtered and its paunch (karşuhu) is set up as a target and shot at, and anyone who hits it gets a share of the meat Kaş. I 403; 16 o.o., same translation: KB (character and knowledge) karında törümiş 'which are formed in the womb' 883; kara karnı toḏsa 'when the common people's bellies are full' 988; ana karnı 'his mother's womb' 1387: xııı(?) At. karın toklukın 'a full belly' 186; Tef. karın aç- 'to be hungry' 201: xıv Muh. al-baṭn karın Mel. 47, 15; Rif. 141; al-cāyi' 'hungry' karna:c (crasis of karnı: a:c) 54, 16; 152; al-ḥaml 'foetus' karında:kı: oğla:n 143: Çağ. xv ff. karn (spelt) şikam wa şikanba 'belly' (Hend.); also called karın San. 272r. 23 (quotn.); same entry reversed 272v. 14: Xwar. xıv karın 'belly' Qutb 134: Kom. xıv ditto CCI, CCG; Gr.: Kıp. xııı al-baṭn karın Hou. 20, 19; 51, 2; al-kirş karın 21, 17: xıv karın al-baṭn İd. 70: xv ditto Kav. 61, 5; Tuh. 7a. 5; al-kirş karın 61, 11; 30b. 5 (also kebe).

D kurun Intrans./Pass. Dev. N. fr. kur-; 'soot', lit. something which establishes itself (on a wall, etc.). Survives as kurun in some NE languages, but everywhere else as kurum (properly a N.S.A.). Cf. 2 ış. Xak. xı kurun 'traces of smoke (aṯaru'l-duxān) which adhere to the walls' Kaş. I 404: (Kom. xıv 'soot' kurum CCG; Gr.).

D kurınç Hap. leg.; Dev. N. fr. kurın-. Uyğ. vııı ff. Bud. közlüg kurınçımıznı séni körmeklig yağmur üze kanturalım 'let us satiate (i.e. alleviate) the dryness of our eyes with the rain of seeing you' U IV 44, 22-4.

meaning: a man with a large belly
full_entry_text: D karna:k Hap. leg.; Dev. N./A. fr. *karna:-, Den. V. fr. karın; the preceding entry is Karna:k balda min bilādi'l-ğuzziya 'one of the Oğuz villages (or districts?)'. Cf. karna:ğu:. Xak. xı karna:k er 'a man with a large belly' ('aẓīmu'l-baṭn) Kaş. I 473.

?F kırna:k 'a slave girl'; a specifically Western word, surviving only(?) in SW Osm. kırnak; Tkm. ğırnak. Perhaps a corruption of Ar. ğurnūq 'a good-looking boy, or girl'. L.-w. in Pe., Doerfer III 1470. Basmıl, Çumul, Ka:y, Kıp., Oğuz, Yaba:ku: xı kırnak al-cāriya 'slave girl' Kaş. I 473: xııı(?) Tef. kırnak 'girl' 209: xıv Muh. al-surrīya 'concubine' kırna:k Mel. 51, 9; Rif. 147; al-cāriya (opposite to élti: 'lady') kırna:k 152 (only): Çağ. xv ff. kırna:ğ/kırna:k (spelt) kanīza ('girl') wa cāriya; also called ğırnak San. 295v. 7; ğırnak 'a word occurring in two languages (muştaraka), in Turkish kanīza wa cariya, in Ar. mard-i camīl 'a handsome man' 262v. 17: Kıp., xııı al-cāriya kırna:k(/kara:wa:ş/kara:ba:ş/tüge:) Hou. 32, 17: xıv kırnak al-cāriya İd. 70: xv ditto Kav. 64, 10 (vocalized karnak); Tuh. 87a. 5; ama 'slave girl' kırnak (and karawaş) do. 3b. 13: Osm. xıv ff. kırnak 'slave girl'; c.i.a.p. TTS I 462; II 632; III 449; IV 514.
E kırŋa:k See kıŋra:k.

D kırın- Refl. f. of kır-; survives only(?) in SW Osm. kırın- 'to cringe'; Tkm. ğırın- 'to cut (etc.) for oneself'. Xak. xı ol ne:ŋni: kırındı: 'he pretended to scrape (or peel, yuqaşşir) the thing' Kaş. II 155 (kırınu:r, kırınma:k).
D koran- hap. leg.; Refl. f. of kora:-; 'to lose flesh'. Uyğ. vııı ff. Civ. H I 104 (korağlığ).

meaning: to defend oneself, to be miserly
full_entry_text: D korın- (korı:n-) Refl. f. of korı:-; s.i.s.m.l. as korın-/korun- 'to defend oneself'. Xak. xı er tava:rıŋa: korındı: (MS. korundi:) 'the man was miserly and niggardly (baxila . . . wa ḍanna) with his money' Kaş. II 155 (korı:nu:r (sic), korınma:k): Çağ. xv ff. korun kendüŋi sakın ḥifẓ eyle 'protect, defend yourself' Vel. 339; korun- mamnū' wa maḥrūs şudan 'to be restricted, protected' San. 285v. 19.

D kurın- Refl. f. of kurı:-; survives in SW Osm. kurun- 'to dry oneself'. Xak. xı er kurundı: (sic) 'the man dried himself (tacaffafa) after washing' Kaş. II 155 (kurınu:r, kurınma:k); kurındı: ne:ŋ 'the thing dried' (caffa) I 505, 7; kurın 'dry yourself' II 160, 7.
S karınça See karınçğa:.

meaning: something which catches or collects soot
full_entry_text: D kurunçı: hap. leg.; N.Ag. fr. kurun; morphologically this should mean 'something which catches or collects soot' or the like. Xak. xı kurunçı: 'felt which has been blackened (iswadda) from the smoke in a tent (etc.)' Kaş. III 242.
S karınçak See karınçğa:.

karınçğa: 'ant'; specifically a Western word; an old animal name ending in -ğa:; the form in Kaş. is aberrant. Survives only(?) in SW Az. ğarışğa; Osm. karınca; Tkm. ğarınca. Cf. çüme:li:, kumursğa:. Oğuz xı karınçak al-naml 'ant', also called karınça: Kaş. I 501; karınça: 'ant' III 375: xıv Rbğ. karınçka (sic) meŋizlik uşak 'as small as an ant' R II 174; Muh. al-naml sarıncak (one MS. adds karınca:) Mel. 74, 6; sırınça: Rif. 177 (Muh. gives no word for 'locust'; the text prob. originally read al-naml <karınça:; al-carād> sarıncak): Çağ. xv ff. karınçğa (spelt) mūrça 'small ant'; also called kumursğa San. 272v. 14: Xwar. xıv karınçka 'ant' Qutb 134: Tkm. xııı al-naml karınca: (Kıp. kumurska:) Hou. 11, 19: xıv al-naml (kımırşağ1: and) karınca: Bul. 11, 5: xv al-naml karınca: Kav. 72, 10; karıncak (Kıp. kumruşka) Tuh. 36b. 2.
D kırındı: Pass. Dev. N./A. fr. kırın-; survives in SW Osm. kırındı/kırıntı; Tkm. ğırındı 'small fragments, crumbs'. Xak. xı kırındı: qaşāra kull şay' 'scrapings of anything' Kaş. I 449.

D karında:ş N. of Assn. fr. karın; lit. 'associated in the womb', that is 'a brother (or sister, usually as kı:z karında:ş) by the same mother', irrespective of seniority and so a more general term than éçi:, ini:, eke:, siŋil, etc. s.i.a.m.l.g., sometimes with a more restricted meaning, e.g. Kk. only 'sister' or a more general one e.g. Osm. also 'comrade'; in SW and some NW languages abbreviated to kardaş. L.-w. in Pe., etc., Doerfer III 1471. Uyğ. vııı ff. Civ. oğul kardaş yeŋeçim 'my son, brother, and sister-in-law' Fam. Arch. 125-6. Xak. xı (after a note on the suffix -da:ş) hence two children (waladayn) out of the same womb are called karındaş; karın means al-baṭn and when -daş is added to it, it gives the meaning muşāhibu'l-baṭn 'associate of the womb' Kaş. I 407: xııı(?) Tef. karandaş/karındaş 'brother' 200-2: xıv Muh. al-xāla 'maternal aunt' karınta:ş ana:; al-'amm 'paternal uncle' ata: karıntaşı: (Mel. kardaşı:); al-uxt 'sister' kı:z karınta:ş; al-ax 'brother' karınta:ş Mel. 49, 6-7; Rif. 144: Çağ. xv ff. kardaş birādar 'brother', an abbreviation of karındaş meaning ham-şikam 'from the same womb' San. 271 v. 26 (quotn.); karındaş 'brother' 272v. 15 (quotn.): Xwar. xııı(?) (Urum Kağan had) bir karundaşı 'one brother' Oğ. 173: xıv karındaş 'brother' Qutb 134: Kom. xıv 'brother' karındaş; 'sister' kız karındaş CCI, CCG; Gr.: Kıp. al-'amm (açkı:/) aţa: karındaşı:; al-ax karında:ş; al-uxt kız karında:ş; awlādu'l-aḥmā' 'brothers-in-law' kayın karında:şla:r Hou. 31, 19: xıv karında:ş al-āx mina'l-baṭn İd. 70; al-āx karında:ş; al-'amm aţa: karında:ş(/eççi:); al-'amma aţa: kız karında:ş; al-xāla ana: kız karında:ş(/ţağza:) Bul. 9, 2: xv bi:niŋ kardaşı: 'the bey's brother' Kav. 27, 5; āx kardaş; uxt kız karındaş Tuh. 3b. 12: Osm. xıv ff. karındaş common till xvı, sporadic till xvııı; karţaş once in xv TTS I 424; II 591; III 414; IV 476.

D karaŋğu: der. fr. kara: but morphologically obscure; 'dark, darkness'. An early l.-w. in Mong. as karaŋğu/karaŋğuy (Haenisch 60; Kow. 838); s.i.a.m.l.g. Uyğ. vııı ff. Bud. karaŋğu kararığığ tarğarğu üçün 'in order to dissipate the dark darkness' Hüen-ts. 185; o.o. Suv. 101, 16 (biligsizlik); USp. 102a. 34 (emgeklig): Xak. xı karaŋğu: al-zulma 'darkness' Kaş. III 388; (a bribe will settle) karaŋku: (sic) ı:şıg al-amra'l-muẓlim 'a nefarious affair' III 217, 1; a.o. III 290 (karva:-): KB karaŋku tüni 'the dark night' 35, 288; karaŋkuda erdim 'I was in darkness' 383; karaŋku ev 'a dark house' 1840: xııı(?) Tef. karaŋğu/karaŋku 'dark, darkness' 200: xıv layl muẓlim 'a dark night' kara:ŋu: tü:n Mel. 80, 9; Rif. 185 (tu:nle:); al-ẓalām (opposite to 'light' ayduŋ) karaŋu: 152 (only): Çağ. xv ff. karaŋğu karaŋu Vel. 320; karaŋğu ẓulm wa tārīk 'darkness' San. 271 v. 14: Xwar. xıv karaŋğu 'dark' Qutb 131: Kom. xıv 'darkness' karaŋğu/karaŋğı CCI, CCG; Gr.: Kıp. xııı (light aydıŋ) al-ẓulma kara:ğu: Hou. 26, 17: xıv al-ẓalām karanı: Bul. 14, 1: xv ẓulma karanğı: Tuh. 24a. 11: Osm. xıv karaŋu/karaŋuluk 'darkness'; c.i.a.p. TTS I 417; II 585; III 419; IV 471.

meaning: a man with a large stomach
full_entry_text: D karna:ğu: Hap. leg.; Dev. N./A. fr. *karna:- cf. karna:k. Xak. xı karnağu: er al-raculu'l-baṭīn 'a man with a large stomach' Kaş. I 491.
D karınlığ P.N./A. fr. karın; s.i.s.m.l., usually for 'pregnant'. Xak. xı beḏük (sic) karınlığ er 'a man with a large stomach' (al-baṭīn) Kaş. I 499.
D kurunluğ P.N./A. fr. kurun; 'sooty'. Survives in SW Az. gurumlu; Osm. kurumlu (sic). Xak. xı kurunluğ ev 'a house blackened (muswadd) by dense smoke' Kaş. I 499.

D karınla:- Dev. N. fr. karın; survives in SW Rep. Turkish for (of a ship) 'to collide with' (a jetty, etc.). Xak. xı (in a para. on the various meanings of Den. V.s in -la:-) ol anı: karınla:dı: baṭanahu, 'he struck him in the stomach' Kaş. III 345, 27; n.m.e.

meaning: to be, or become, black or dark
full_entry_text: D kara:r- Intrans. Den. V. fr. kara:; 'to be, or become, black or dark'. S.i.s.m.l. Uyğ. vııı ff. Man. kararmış köŋüllüg 'with darkened minds' TT III 89: Bud. (of a dying man) tılı ağızı kararıp 'his tongue and mouth become black' Suv. 595, 14: Xak. xı tü:n karardı: 'the night was dark' (aẓlama); and one says to:n karardı: 'the garment (etc.) was black' (iswadda) Kaş. II 77 (kara:rur (sic), kararma:k): xııı(?) Tef. karar- 'to become dark' 200: Çağ. xv ff. karar- (spelt) 'to become black or dark' (siyāh wa tīra) San. 268v. 18 (quotns.): Xwar. xıv ditto Qutb 132: Kom. xıv ditto CCI, CCG; Gr.: Kıp. xv iswadda karar- Kav. 5, 14; (the Den. V. fr.) kara is karar- Tuh. 83b. 5.
D kurır- (kurı:r-) Hap. leg.; Inchoative f. of kurı:-; cf. kurğa:ḏ-. Xak. xı kurırdı: ne:ŋ 'the thing began to dry' (tawaccaha . . . li'l-cafāf) Kaş. II 77 (kurı:rur (sic), kurırma:k).

D karart- Caus. f. of karar-; 'to darken, blacken'. S.i.s.m.l. Xak. xı ol anıŋ to:nın kararttı: 'he blackened (sawwada) his garment' (etc.) Kaş. III 431 (karartur, karartma:k): KB (the king was angry and) artuk kararttı meŋiz 'made his face even blacker' (i.e. fiercer) 629; a.o. 639: xııı(?) Tef. karart- 'to blacken' 200: Çağ. xv ff. karart- Caus. f.; siyāh kardan 'to blacken' San. 269r. 4 (quotns.): Xwar. xıv ditto Qutb 132.

D kararığ Dev. N./A. fr. karar-; 'dark, darkness'. N.o.a.b. Uyğ. vııı ff. Man.-A M I 9, 1 (tünerig); do. 19, 11 (i) (alaŋadtur-): Man. kararığ nızvanıları 'their dark passions' TT III 114: Bud. yekniŋ içgeknig kararığ ışıŋa 'the dark doings of demons and vampires' TT VI 273; (in this world the sky is called 'light', and the brown earth below) kararığ 'darkness' (the sun is called 'light', and the moon 'darkness', man 'light', and woman 'darkness') do. 319-21; o.o. Kuan. 66 (kögüzlüg); Hüen-ts. 185 (karaŋğu:).

1 kars some kind of 'garment'; n.o.a.b. L.-w. in Pe., Doerfer III 1457. Uyğ. vııı ff. Bud. PP 2, 4-5 (boḏut-): Xak. xı kars 'an outer garment (al-kisā') of camels' hair or sheeps' wool' Kaş. I 348; (patch brocade with brockade) kars yama:ğı: karska: 'and a woollen (garment, al-şūf) with woollen (fabric)' Kaş. III 28, 17 (MS. has karış which makes no sense and is obviously an error for kars): Çağ. xv ff. kars (rhyming with pārs) 'a shawl (şāl) and anything (similar) which they wrap round their waists' San. 271 v. 29.
